text: She was working at a topless place when I stopped in for a beer. I just kept looking at the front of my face in the spotlight so clear. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: For sale: presidency. No offers refused.
author: danielradosh

text: Ride or die
author: danielradosh

text: We ended up with socialism
author: danielradosh

text: Would just like to point out that this was not a widely shared opinion when I tweeted it in October 2017.
author: danielradosh

text: Pretty sure this is lyrics from a Street-Legal outtake. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Revelation speaks of 2 witnesses and 30,000 retweets
author: danielradosh

text: It did not.
author: danielradosh

text: Your periodic reminder that in the original book, Soylent Green was made out of SOY and LENTils but that was too disgusting for movie audiences so they changed it.
author: danielradosh

text: Here's a song I've never heard: Ain't Gonna Go To Hell For Anybody. It's not on any album, and it certainly is good enough to have been. The lyrics strike me a more self-aware, ethical twist on All I Really Wanna Do. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: I've heard this expressed & so far I'm not sure why? The live versions are quite good--but so are the studio ones! I wonder if the Bootleg simply gave people a chance to listen again with fresh ears. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Frantically googling suggestions for an 5-10 essential episode rewatch... nothing coming up...
author: danielradosh

text: You hear that, Florida Men? You've got exactly 2 weeks to plan something spectacular for @tomtomorrow!
author: danielradosh

text: My Florida Man story is... not funny
author: danielradosh

text: Somewhere (maybe some #BD969 follower knows where) Bob said it was ironic that the people who used to beg him relentlessly to be a leader and tell them the answers rejected him completely when he finally tried. Of course he should've realized he was right not to do it all along.
author: danielradosh

text: BTW I love the Todd Haynes movie I'm Not There but this is the one period it gets badly wrong. Bob didn't retreat into church basements. He tried hard to bring the Word to the masses at stadium shows. They just didn't want to hear it. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Next on #BD969: the live Bootleg Series from this period. It's always struck me as crazy that people went out and accused Dylan of betraying them with this Christian bullshit not 15 years after he made the people who accused him of betrayal for going electric look like idiots.
author: danielradosh

text: The theory that the Conway marriage is an intentional ploy to play both sides so they can have a post-Trump career either way is belied by the obvious fact that her association with Trump will in now way hurt her no matter what.
author: danielradosh

text: So what does Bob still believe about God after all this? Well, it's simple, and complicated, and one of the finest songs of his career. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: That's the animating idea of Summertime, echoing the CCM classic Take Me Back. Andrae Crouch is no longer in God's presence but "I still I hear you calling me," just Bob's summer with God has ended but he's "still carrying the gift you gave." #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: The key to unlocking Shot of Love is the gorgeous In the Summertime. Evangelicals often speak of how when they first accept Jesus the relationship is immediate & intense, but as time goes on those qualities recede. They wonder, can I recapture that? And if not, what next? #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Who is Bob talking to when he says Lenny Bruce was "more of an outlaw than you ever were"? Maybe someone who conceives of followers of Jesus as the true outlaws. Keep in mind that Bob came to Christian rock through Larry Norman. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: lmfaaoooo
author: danielradosh

text: lmao at Biden thinking pledging to 1 term & picking a young running mate will alleviate concerns about his age. Trump would love that! "Why would you vote for someone who thinks he's can't last 2 terms and might die in office folks? I could do this job for 3 terms if you let me!"
author: danielradosh

text: As a harasser, Michael Steinhardt was creepily fixated on fertility and procreation. Want to guess what's going on at Birthright Israel, the organization he co-founded? https://jewishcurrents.org/birthright-israel-and-metoo/ …
author: danielradosh

text: Because if Lenny is in hell, Woody is in hell, so maybe there's more to this. "Lenny Bruce" is Bob wrestling with the idea that maybe Good and Bad can't be defined quite clear somehow, and what that means for his belief. He's looking at what the Light actually shows him. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: If Lenny's name came up in Bob's new circles, someone, using Gotta Serve Somebody logic, would likely point out that he was in hell. And it wouldn't shock me if that's what made Bob, who had accepted that his family & friends were going to burn, think, That can't be right. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Stick with me. I have A Theory. The overarching theme of SoL is Bob growing as Christian, becoming comfortable with doubt. See, even if you wanted to write a tribute to Lenny Bruce why do it as a defense? Who's out there saying he cut babies' heads off? But trust me... #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: With SoL Bob is changing as an artist (shocker) but it's all Christian rock, informed by his new worldview rather than trying to sell his new worldview. But crucially I think is Christian worldview is also changing. And I think that's what Lenny Bruce is doing here. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: People call Shot of Love a "partly Christian" album. Because they're thinking in separational terms . I think it was T-Bone Burnett who said of Christian music: You can sing about the Light or you can sing about what the Light allows you to see. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Property of Jesus, a song I definitely didn't know before, is hilariously bitchy. It's basically a Christian Positively 4th Street. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Shot of Love has one of Dylan's all-time masterpieces, his best song of the decade, but overall it's a mess. Weird mishmash of styles, muddy production, and wild swings in musical and lyrical quality. It's also possible I've never listened to it straight through before. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: The weird faces are scary
author: danielradosh

text: That said, Saved is much more listenable than I remember. Now let’s see about Shot of Love. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Saved suffers from the departure of Knopfler, and other than incredible harmonica on What Can I Do For You not much stands out musically. Again though the real weak link is the lyrics. Instead of Bob's singular vision we get warmed over Hal Lindsey. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: You can find the video but it's like playing whack-a-mole
author: danielradosh

text: Anyway the original would have landed about four rows higher on my list. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Supposedly the original Saved album cover was scrapped post-release by chickenshit label execs and replaced with the inferior less-religious one, but I find it hard to believe Bob didn't have the clout to stop that. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Who are they going to get to play a middle aged Keanu?
author: danielradosh

text: Bob almost didn't include Man Gave Names To All The Animals on STC but then he found out that children liked it. It's had success as a kids song ever since and has been adapted as a picture book. The ending is mildly interesting but otherwise... #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Some of the best moments on Slow Train Coming are when Bob examines his own soul. The third great song on the album is When He Returns, which can be read as a response to Blowin' In The Wind. How many times must the cannonballs fly? Glad you asked, pipsqueak... #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Of course evangelical pop culture can't be separated from evangelical politics, and Bob's born again phase also marks a shift from left-wing populism to quasi right-wing nationalism.  #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: I've never listened to this Bootleg Series album. Can't wait to get to it.
author: danielradosh

text: Bob really just takes a spiritual shotgun to everyone on Slow Train. The capitalists, the hippies, the pious. I can see why people hated it at the time, but it's pretty glorious. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: This fire & brimstone is a real balancing act. When he pulls it off--for me the title track is the best song on Slow Train--Bob is an angry prophet whose words convict your heart. When he doesn't--Change My Way of Thinking--he's just a bitter scold. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: The genius of I Believe In You is to recast the familiar God is my girlfriend trope as a defiant anthem of forbidden love. It's theologically correct for evangelicalism but rare in CCM, which tends to lean to heartwarming for this kind of song. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: This is exactly right. For the first time in ages Bob sings like he means every word. I love it most on I Believe In You where tbh he's bleating like a strangled goat but with such passion and intensity that it draws you in completely. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Now that the main #BD969 thread has reached Bob Dylan's born again period, here's a look back (11 years!!) at my list of other Christian rock songs that don't suck.
author: danielradosh

text: For Gotta Serve Somebody Bob rewrites a 1972 song by ur-Christian rocker Larry Norman, who was himself heavily influenced by Dylan. He probably does it for the usual reasons--Love & Theft--but the Christian community took it as a signal of membership. I prefer LN's lyrics. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: If you read the book I’d be very curious to hear how you think things have changed in the 10 years since it came out. I haven’t really kept up.
author: danielradosh

text: This is why the lyrics on the STC album aren't Bob's best (though certain songs work). He seems to be fighting the genre constraints. But musically STC is nearly unimpeachable. Mark Knopfler! Muscle Shoals Horns! And Bob sings w strength, passion & sometimes even a tune! #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: I have not!
author: danielradosh

text: I see you're Twitter connected to both @LoriLenz and @jaybakker. Both of them were a huge help to me back in the day!
author: danielradosh

text: Slow Train Coming is by intention Separational CCM. Basic principles: keep me set apart & don't wanna confuse nobody. S-CCM demands (see tweet above) straightforward propositional claims. No irony, as one fan told me. This is, to say the least, not a natural fit for Bob. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Getting ahead of myself here but Every Grain of Sand marks his switch from separational CCM to transformational. An important (and wonderful) song.
author: danielradosh

text: Remember kids, I wrote a pretty cool book about Christian pop culture so I have Thoughts about Contemporary Christian Music (CCM). This excerpt is important context for what Bob's about to do as #BD969 hits 1979:
author: danielradosh

text: The next stretch of #BD969 is gonna be fun. Dylan's Christian trilogy is his most underrated period. To be clear, when I said Planet Waves was underrated I meant people think of it as only OK but it's great. Now I mean people hate the Christian period... but it's pretty good!
author: danielradosh

text: And finally (for now) here is #BD969 Part Three: 1970-1978
author: danielradosh

text: @threadreaderapp unroll
author: danielradosh

text: And #BD969 Part 2b:
author: danielradosh

text: For whatever reason this thread seems to break @threadreaderapp so Part Two: 1965-1969 is itself in two parts. Here's #BD969 Part 2a:
author: danielradosh

text: @threadreaderapp unroll
author: danielradosh

text: This seems like a good place to end Part Three of #BD969. The journey through dark heat continues here:
author: danielradosh

text: The #BD969 thread is now being born again right here. In case you missed it, I am listening to all 969(ish) officially released Bob Dylan songs in chronological(ish) order. If you're just joining us, here is an unrolled version of Part One: 1961-1964:
author: danielradosh

text: I don't know what that means but it's fantastic
author: danielradosh

text: But on the whole At Budokan is Bob Dylan with the edges sanded off. This would be very much at home on late 70s AOR radio, which is not a compliment. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: There's some interesting failures on Bob Dylan At Budokan: Don't Think Twice as ska? All I Really Want To Do by way of Simon & Garfunkel? But the best tracks are the swampy take on Oh Sister and a mesmerizingly eerie I Want You.  #BD969
author: danielradosh

text:
Desire: Dylan discovers violin
Street Legal: Dylan discovers saxophone
Budokan: Dylan discovers flute
Slow Train: Dylan discovers Jesus
I know! I was worried it was gonna be accordion! 
#BD969 #DadHumor
author: danielradosh

text: I don't know this story!
author: danielradosh

text: I tend to think about the meaning of Dylan songs in terms of their overall gestalt while some people like to really get lost in the weeds, but either approach is informative. It's purely a matter of taste. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: This particular analysis is a little overdetermined for my taste, but I've always seen it generally as a Christ story in the Old West.
author: danielradosh

text: Dylan's set on The Last Waltz is pure . Better than his own live album with the Band, or any other live stuff he officially released around this time. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: One neat thing about doing #BD969 complete & chronological is the patterns you start to see. With Señor I realize just how many cowboy/Western stories Bob has written (as distinct from country western songs, though there's overlap). That would make a pretty good playlist.
author: danielradosh

text: The 2nd half of SL exceeds the low bar of the 1st. The not good songs are at least not actively terrible and of the songs I thought were stellar, Señor is decent & Where Are You Tonight is almost stellar. I love how the quickening tempo compliments the bracing lyrics. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Also 9-10am if I get into work early
author: danielradosh

text: That’s a lie! The no masturbating rule would definitely not prevent me from joining the Proud Boys!

text: How come when Gus Grissom says he fucked the pooch he's cool but when I say I *didn't* fuck the cat, I'm gross??
author: danielradosh

text: That's a good way to do it too.
author: danielradosh

text: The Fugitive (1993)
author: danielradosh

text: Not that I've noticed. Maybe 7-9pm is the most frequent time?  But hopefully it catches everyone at some point in the day and then you can scroll back and catch up.
author: danielradosh

text: Bob's voice is peak whiny on Street Legal which really drives home the awfulness of Is Your Love In Vain. Mid-60s Bob is a dick to the women in his songs but he pulls it off bc he's funny & charming too. Here's it's just demanding, snotty & manipulative. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: ICYMI (an initialism Bob probably also coined) here is Bob coining "I can't even" in 1966 #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: To quote a phrase coined by Dylan, I can't even with this saxophone. And half the lyrics sound like Bob is just throwing darts at a rhyming dictionary. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Is there a word for the tendency of Dylan fans to claim that his obviously bad albums are secretly great? Because that was me w Street Legal. I used to think the whole album was good and 2 songs stellar. I haven't gotten to those 2 yet, but the other ones are pretty bad. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Remember when Fox turned Solyndra into a 6 month scandal?
author: danielradosh

text: just say lol
author: danielradosh

text: The thing is when I started #BD969 I knew in the back of my mind that I was going to reach 1978 eventually. I remember Street Legal as the first Dylan album I taped from my dad’s LPs as a teen after I already had all the essential ones and decided I was going to really dig in.
author: danielradosh

text: In between these two albums is a minor but worth hearing Dylan song that he performed as a duet with Eric Clapton called Sign Language. It includes the immortal line, "It was there at the bakery / surrounded by fakery." #BD969
author: danielradosh

text:
*cops break up fight* 
"Right what's this all about?"
"Whether Hard Rain is Bob Dylan's third or fourth best live album."
"... You know what, just kill each other."
"Not counting the Bootleg Series of course."
*cops leave*
author: danielradosh

text: Hard Rain is mostly meh. Bob adopts this annoying sing-songy approach that undermines otherwise great songs. I remember why I never listened to it much. BUT toward the end there is an extraordinary & transformative version of You're A Big Girl Now! #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: #BD969 hits 2 live albums, the recently released 1975 bootleg & the 1976 Hard Rain album. The former is so much better it really makes you wonder why they didn't just release that at the time. Check out Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall as a blistering blues song.
author: danielradosh

text: There are a handful of changes registered above that are really just differences in punctuation but my point is someone with the diff utility and a few days to spare could easily make Bobchecker with every song pre-loaded for browsing. #ItAintMeBabe #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: If you look compare the original Tonight I'll Be Staying Here With You to the version that kicks off the 1975 Live Bootleg you can see Bob basically took entire fantastic song and then wrote an almost completely different fantastic song on top of it. #BD969 #diffchecker
author: danielradosh

text: #BD969 update: There actually is a site that lets you see changes to lyrics: @diffchecker. I have a Mac so I can't download the desktop version that would show 2 texts in a unified file but even the basic features makes something clear...
author: danielradosh

text: Two things I want legal Twitter to weigh in on: Is it true that Hurricane Carter wouldn't have been able to appeal his sentence had the 1996 Effective Death Penalty Act been in effect and 2) Is sentencing based on time of day common in mafia cases?  #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Nate the Great was my favorite series to read aloud when my kids were little because I got to do a Bogart impression #wnbk
author: danielradosh

text: That tweet is the first thing that’s ever made me want a blue check
author: danielradosh

text: “A lot of people don’t know this but it’s just sunglasses and a wig, folks. I knew always, but people tell me all the time they had no idea.”
author: danielradosh

text: He just figured out that Hannah is really Miley
author: danielradosh

text: I think maybe I broke the #BD969 thread?
author: danielradosh

text: Someone somewhere said accurately that the live version of Isis (released on Biograph) is like suddenly hearing the song in 3D. Given that, I'm looking forward to the next stretch of #BD969: the live Rolling Thunder Revue Bootleg Series.
author: danielradosh

text: It probably will be, which is why it's not anywhere else. I'll just buy the blu-ray.
author: danielradosh

text: Update: If you ever want the entire internet to tweet All That Jazz at you, this is the way to do it. (On a related note: All That Jazz is not streaming anywhere, even for purchase!)
author: danielradosh

text: As someone interested but not terribly familiar what should I watch before this comes out?
author: danielradosh

text: Sorry. It should be on Spotify etc. no offense to ordinary citizens...
author: danielradosh

text: In that case another one you might like is Golden Loom.
author: danielradosh

text: To me, it's on par with something like Romance in Durango. It could easily have worked, but I'm not shocked he left it off as I am with Abandoned Love.
author: danielradosh

text: It's... not good.
author: danielradosh

text: There are a handful of Desire outtakes but only one that matters. Dylan has this thing of leaving great work off his albums. We saw it with Up To Me and now here's what would've been the best song on Desire save Isis and maybe Black Diamond Bay. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Finally, I'm of two minds about Sara. It's overly sentimental and he lays on the glamorous nymph crap pretty thick, but it's kind of touching despite that, and "so easy to look at, so hard to define," is an amazing insight about how it feels to be in love with someone. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: After Isis the Desire song I love most is Black Diamond Bay, a toe-tapping To Have and Have not fantasia that weaves an elaborate multi-character tragicomic farce before ending with one of my favorite Dylan punchlines: #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: On the other hand, Desire is really where Dylan's indulgence in exoticism really gets the best of him. The romanticization of the untamed other is an unfortunate part of his artistic vision throughout his career, but it really comes to the fore on this album. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Once again, listening to Dylan now that I'm more familiar with Frank Sinatra and how much Bob liked him, i'd guess that Mozambique is really no more than Bob trying his hand at one of those exotic travel songs Sinatra loved so much, and quite successfully. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Joey is not a good song. I don't have a big problem with whitewashing and romanticizing killers for the sake of art. Nobody complained when he did it with John Wesley Hardin(g). But when you get to something like this, sorry, I'm out. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: One thing I'll say about Hurricane is that it's a well-told story, somehow smarter and more subtle than the film version, although Denzels is very good. The verse about the criminals in their coats and ties is a nice throwback to Woody Guthrie. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Isis is a hell of a song. Some Weird West Jonah Hex shit. The lyrics are great all the way through, but it's this dialogue at the end that captures the classic laconic masculinity of the Westerns. My favorite song on the album. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: This can't be true right? Not to mention, asking a woman carrying a violin case if she can really play violin is definitely the musician equivalent of "I bet you don't really play video games." She should've told him to fuck off. But thank god she didn't, because Desire. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Would Desire be a good album w/out Emmylou Harris and Scarlet Rivera on violin? I know it's a dumb question because it has them, so what difference does it make, but it occurs to me that some of these songs are getting a free ride (Oh Sister, more like oh brother amirite!) #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Turns out that's all I have to say about The Basement Tapes. Sure, Nothing Was Delivered is pretty great and You Ain't Goin Nowhere (though I miss the verse about feeding the cats) but clearly I don't see what other people do in this album, so let's move on to Desire. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: I had in mind outtakes and live versions. As long as Bob is still performing a song in concert the lyrics are never fixed.
author: danielradosh

text: Because most of the songs on them are in the playlist with the albums they originally appeared on. The songs that aren’t on albums (standalone singles & greatest hits only tracks) were released on a cd called side tracks, and I’ve pulled them from that to sprinkle into the list.
author: danielradosh

text: That might have sold it for me. I didn’t know anyone else even remembered the Friday the 23th series.
author: danielradosh

text: When no one RTs my meme
author: danielradosh

text: BCT has been such a great experience for our kids— 2 girls and 1 boy and, yes, none of that nonsense. Thanks for supporting it!
author: danielradosh

text: #BD969 has reached The Basement Tapes, which I've slotted into 1975 when they were buffed up and released, having already listened to The Basement Tapes Raw Bootleg Series back in 67. So far, I like the Raw tracks a lot more. This sounds much more like a Band album.
author: danielradosh

text: Beto's high school poetry is so much better than mine.
author: danielradosh

text: I don't really know Van Ronk as well as I should. Thanks for the tip.
author: danielradosh

text: Now that you say it, I think you could argue that the reason Christian rock works is that idealized women in pop music serve the same role as the Christ who suffers and sacrifices in order to save others. Makes changing the lyrics from her to Him easy.
author: danielradosh

text: I take back what I said about Dirge. If there's really one obscure Dylan song I'd urge any more casual fan to check out, it's Up To Me. This outtake from Blood On The Tracks is as great as almost any song on the album, and that's saying a lot. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P-zxYpCVo_M … #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: SFTS traverses from creation to crucifixion, with the narrator simultaneously sufferer, prophet and savior. For the first time, Dylan's Bible references are not mere literary window dressing, they are theological touchstones. Thank you for coming to my Ted Talk. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: But SFTS is the 1st song built around the expression of a Christian idea: sinful man separated from God & yearning for salvation through Christ. And obviously it's a love song too. Great art has layers of meaning. But in essence it's a Christian gloss on the Book of Isaiah #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: To be sure, Dylan has used biblical imagery from the start of his career & has expounded on Christian ideas, including elsewhere on Blood on the Tracks, as in this line from Idiot Wind (certainly a clever paraphrase of salvation through suffering and sacrifice). #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Digression time: Christian rock can be roughly fit into 3 slots. The type most people think of--and what Bob would embrace in his "Christian phase"--is separational. Shelter is transformational. For more, I highly recommend this book that I wrote. #BD969 https://www.amazon.com/Rapture-Ready-Adventures-Parallel-Christian/dp/159376281X …
author: danielradosh

text: Now a quick dip into Shelter From The Storm, significant as Dylan's first true Christian song & also the greatest Christian rock song ever. Many people wouldn't categorize it as such b/c Xian rock is often defined by a certain type of song--unsubtle & didactic--but it is. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: This is just about the cover art! I love JWH.
author: danielradosh

text: Oh right, keeping your cards hidden. I get it now. #jackofhearts #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: I haven't noticed this rhetorical trick on other albums but on BOTT Bob frequently tells his stories by leaving out information. The main events of Lily Rosemary takes place in between the vignettes we actually hear. Or even this line from Tangled says so much indirectly. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: wonderful!
author: danielradosh

text: I used to drive my kids crazy by always selecting Tangled Up In Blue in Rock Band 2. Unfortunately there's no sound on this video because YouTube comes down hard on copyright violations even though they can't somehow manage to ban fucking nazis. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: I'd love to see someone apply the @newsdiffs approach to Dylan songs--tracking how the lyrics change in different versions. I'm shocked it doesn't exist. This is the 2nd time I've wondered if the Dylanology community has aged out of technology that would serve it well. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: I'm glad Bob kept working on this verse of If You See Her. The final version (rt) is miles better. Blaming fate is a boring cop out. In the end he takes responsibility-- in an implicit rebuke to the younger Bob of If You Gotta Go, Go Now (or else you gotta stay all night) #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: These 3 verses are a short film, with not just the narrative of the relationship & its end plus some mystical symbolism but soundtrack, cinematography, crosscut edits. And it does what a film can't, introducing a 1st person narrator who is also the 3rd person protagonist. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Which versions of BOTT is better? Both astound in different ways. NY is bracingly raw and immediate, but the polish and remove of the final enhances the storytelling, which is one of the things I love. BOTT conveys hours, days and lifetimes in the briefest sketch of words. #BD969
author: danielradosh

text: Beto/Booker ticket doomed by irreconcilable differences over feelings about dead cows
author: danielradosh
